text: What do you think about it?   /
I know they're really strict right now because my hundr-, husband is from out of the country  /
and, uh, we had to go through a whole, very long process to, uh, to, assure the government that he was, uh, marrying me --
-- and not to be a resident here. /
I think that's, uh, I think it's a little crazy.  /
and just, it was incredible to me to see the things that they had to go through when they were really some of the best workers. /
I mean, you can't just come over to the country because, uh, you want to. /
You know, that's not good enough.  /
You have to have a, have to have a darn good reason of, political or whatever. /
Not a good, not a good easy way to get in. /
I think, you know, I think in a lot of ways the law is good because it tries to, to protect, you know, the people who are in the states. /
My mother, uh, actually knew a woman <breathing> in another state that used to marry men --
n-, she'd never even meet them  /
and she'd just get money for it. /
Sounds like a lot of fun.  /
it's amazing to me how, how many things they would allow to occur before, you know, you can come in. /
But, I mean, with the new laws, it's --
it's kind of frustrating, too, for those who are legitimate now. /
Well, and, you know, uh, my grandparents came to this country just wanting a better life, you know -- /
but now it's a, you know, it's so strict that you can't just do <door> that. /
And I think it's important that they, you know, they allow a good number of people in every year  /
because really they're the ones who work the hardest and do the jobs that, that we don't want to do. /
I have, personally I have a problem with it,  /
I think, that, you know, if someone wants to come in and they can prove that they're going to work and they're going to be a good citizen that --
If they're not going to be on welfare or, or, or whatever.  /
They're going to be a productive citizen Zen. /
And, you know, I, I believe that if someone goes on welfare that's when, you, you know, send them back to their country. /
And, I think a lot of times we're so busy trying to keep them out that we're spending twice as much money as we would just allowing them in  /
Well, think of how many illegal aliens have, have, have been, uh, uh, sent back to Mexico just to find their way back. /
and that's, that's what I think.  /
You know, I, I have to laugh  /
because, like I said, I worked with a lot of those  /
and they'd been deported two or three times  /
and just basically what they do is they get caught when they wanted to go home for Christmas.
But, I think, you know, I think all in all there's a lot of improvements.  /
I think the general idea is good  /
but, but there could be some work done in the area. /
Anyway, do you have anything else in the, the subject, uh --
-- that you might want to talk about?  /
-- this is spur of the moment, uh,  /
but, I, I don't really see any, any changes that I think of really blatant right now  /
other than I think they ought to take, you know, on a case by case basis and not necessarily make it a, uh, political refugee. /
I think a lot of times we take, you know, basically who we want to  /
because if you, if you have connections, it's a lot easier to get in. /
and I think, you know, it should be more of a thing that's based upon someone's intent, you know.
And that it should be equal to all  /
and then not like the United States, - /
basically, it's not who you know,  /
it d-, it doesn't become a thing of who you know, but, but how the type of person you are. /
And it should be based on those kinds of things so the good people, like probably your husband, can get in <laughter>. /
Well, we got him past that,  /
-- I know there's a lot of other people out there,
would probably do a good job here. /
is there anything I believe in <laughter>. /
Is this like a very short call?  <Laughter>. /
I'm not sure how long they're supposed to be,  /
It's good hearing your, your point of view  /
I think we agree a lot on that  /
<Laughter> Well, it was nice talking to you. /
You have a good evening, all right? /
